Since 2015, both brands have recalled more than 2.3 million cars total because of increased fire risks. By 2019, the companies had many cases of fires not associated with crashes.The cars have demonstrated two times the risk of being involved in a non-crash fire compared to comparable vehicles from competing brands. The risks were so severe that owners were advised to park their cars outside and away from houses or other cars.Since 2010 more than 3,100 Hyundai and Kia vehicles have caught fire, injuring 103 people and killing one, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), the government agency investigating both automakers.
